tossups.question: Matt Goldby's Gideon Project targeted two of these locations with pipebombs in 1984. Clayton Waagner sent 550 anthrax letters to these locations. The "Atomic Dog" James Kopp sniped the manager of one of these locations named Barnett Slepian. Operation Rescue's “Truth Trucks” park near these locations. It's not a nightclub, but before the 1996 Centennial Park Bombings, Eric Rudolph killed a security guard during a bombing of one of these locations. So called TRAP laws are meant to restrict access to these locations. The first of these locations was opened in Brownsville, New York by Margaret Sanger. tossups.question: A point mutation in a protein found in this substance can cause Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease; that protein is proteolipid protein. HHV-6 may cause cross-reactivity with a protein found in this substance that is encoded by a section of the gene for Golli. This substance must be "cleared" before later stages of Wallerian degeneration. This substance's namesake "basic protein" is deficient in shiverer mice, which are common models for leukodystrophies. Autoimmune attacks on this substance can cause Guillain–Barré ("ghee-YANN ba-RAY") syndrome and multiple sclerosis. Saltatory conduction involves jumps along gaps in this substance called the Nodes of Ranvier. For 10 points, name this lipid-rich substance that Schwann cells fashion into a "sheath" for axons.
tossups.answer: myelin [accept the myelin sheath or myelin basic protein]

tossups.question: Luis (loo-EES) Bush argued that these people should focus their efforts on a region he called the "10/40 window" ("ten forty window"). Many of these people use Henry Venn and Rufus Anderson's three-self formula, which emphasizes self-governance, self-support, and self-propagation. The Lausanne (LUH-zen) Movement emphasized the need for these people to work with "unreached people groups," often using translations provided by the Wycliffe Global Alliance. These people may be inspired by a passage from the Book of Matthew called the Great Commission. The modern sense of this term was coined to describe Jesuits such as Matteo Ricci (mah-TAY-oh REE-chee), who traveled to China and other countries. tossups.answer: Christian missionaries [or evangelists]

tossups.question: The speaker says of this poet, "They dressed you in light but you dreamed / with the night" in a June Jordan poem titled for "Something Like a Sonnet for" this poet. Alice Walker uses this author as an example to refute Virginia Woolf's idea that a woman must have money and a room of one's own. This poet, who is praised as a "pious youth" in an address by Jupiter Hammon, wrote "An Address to the Atheist." This poet lists "A crown, a mansion, and a throne that shine" in a poem which invokes Columbia and begins, "Celestial choir! enthron'd in realms of light." A poem by this poet begins, "'Twas mercy brought me from my Pagan land." tossups.answer: Phillis Wheatley

tossups.question: One of these objects contains the Lord's Prayer and a letter in the installation Messages to Papa. Popular motifs on these objects included two depicting a "hugging bear" or the leg of a "fair-haired old man." Women officially owned these objects and used bull boats to catch rain from them. These objects were arranged to resemble the "sacred hoop" and were dissembled to create wagon-like travois (trav-wuh). It's not mountains or a swastika, but the Denver International Airport resembles these objects, which are similar to lavvu (LOV-voo) used by the Sami (SAH-mee). tossups.question: An estimate for this quantity at maximum power, assuming irreversibility, is named after Chambadal and Novikov. The fact that two constructs with different values for this quantity would allow for reversed heat flow motivated a theorem that follows from the second law of thermodynamics and gives an upper bound on this quantity. The Kelvin-Planck statement also gives an upper bound on this quantity. The maximum possible value of this quantity is achieved by a cycle consisting of two isothermal and two adiabatic processes, and it is one minus the ratio of the temperatures of the two reservoirs for that cycle named for Carnot (car-NOH). tossups.question: A tension between this principle and individual freedom was illustrated with an example involving the characters "Lewd" and "Prude" who disagree about what to do with a copy of Lady Chatterley's Lover. Amartya Sen proved there is no social choice function which satisfies this property and also allows more than one individual to be decisive over a pair of alternatives, a result called the "liberal paradox." Arrow's impossibility theorem shows that there's no non-dictatorial social welfare function satisfying universal domain, IIA (eye-eye-A), and this property. Every competitive equilibrium has this property according to the first theorem of welfare economics. tossups.question: These molecules can be stabilized by stapling on a hydrocarbon as a covalent cross-link. Robert Merrifield won the 1984 Nobel for binding these molecules to resin, allowing reagents to be washed over them in between protection steps and accelerating the process of elongation. tossups.question: In "Empiricism, Semantics, and Ontology," Rudolf Carnap identifies "internal" questions as those whose answers are either factual or have this property. In a 1956 "defense," H. P. Grice and P. F. Strawson attempted to give a use-based account of this property based on whether expressions have the same answer to the question "What does it mean?" In Language, Truth, and Logic, A. J. Ayer argues that all meaningful propositions are either verifiable, or have this property. W.V.O. Quine's "Two Dogmas of Empiricism" argues that this property cannot be reduced to "cognitive synonymy." For 10 points, name this property of statements that are true by definition, which shares its name with the dominant philosophical style in the United States and Great Britain.
tossups.answer: analytic propositions [or analyticity; prompt on meaning or synonymy or truth]

Txillardegi (chee-ARK-deg-ee), who wrote the first Basque novel, was much inspired by this Basque-born Spanish-language author of the Generation of '98, whose "nivolas" include Niebla and Abel Sanchez.

The development of Basque literature almost ceased for two decades after this war. In Sartre's 1939 story The Wall, Ramon Gris is accidentally betrayed by Pablo Ibbieta during this war, and ends up shot by Nationalists.

bonuses.leadin: The Hamiltonian of this system is proportional to the number operator plus one-half. For 10 points each:
answers: quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO; prompt on partial answers; do not prompt on or accept "simple harmonic oscillator" or "SHO"]
creation and annihilation operators [accept raising operator in place of creation and lowering operator in place of annihilation; accept ladder operators]
parts: Name this quantum mechanical system whose solutions are proportional to products of Gaussian functions and Hermite polynomials. It is the quantum analogue of a simple classical system used to model springs.

The number operator is the product of these objects, which can be used to find the eigenvalues of a QHO’s Hamiltonian without solving exactly. They are denoted a and a-dagger, and correspond to either adding or removing a quantum of energy from the system.
This other operator is defined in terms of the ladder operators and a complex quantity denoted alpha. This unitary operator generates coherent states.
answers_formatted: quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO; prompt on partial answers; do not prompt on or accept "simple harmonic oscillator" or "SHO"]
creation and annihilation operators [accept raising operator in place of creation or lowering operator in place of annihilation; accept ladder operators]

bonuses.leadin: A book titled after this intellectual movement claims it is characterized by the replacement of "parody" with "pastiche." For 10 points each:
answers: metanarratives [or grand narratives; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify this movement, which is called "the cultural logic of late capitalism" in that book by Frederic Jameson. This intellectual movement emerged as a response to modernity.
Jean-François Lyotard's The Postmodern Condition claims postmodernism is characterized by an "incredulity" to these totalizing stories about historical progress.
A fake quote from Ecclesiastes opens this Jean Baudrillard book, which argues that postmodernity is characterized by a "hyperreality" in which signs have no referents.

bonuses.leadin: In an origin story for this holiday, a king ascends to the sky while sitting on a jeweled throne and dispels the harsh winter. For 10 points each:
answers: Nowruz [or Persian New Year; or Iranian New Year; prompt on New Year]
cleaning one's house [or spring cleaning; accept sweeping; accept obvious equivalents like decluttering]
Shia Islam [or Shi'ism; accept Twelver Shia or Imamiyyah]
parts: Name this holiday that originally joined 6 Gahambar (gah-huhm-buhr) feasts on a religious calendar. On the eve of this day, a family will huddle around a Haft-Sin, on which 7 foods that start with the letter S are laid.

Families will perform this general action in the "shaking the house" ceremony that precedes the Persian New Year. This action should be done the day before Chinese New Year to create space for good luck, but not on the day itself.
Nowruz is celebrated by this branch of Islam since it coincides with the Event of Ghadir Khumm (gha-deer koom), which is interpreted as Muhammad declaring that Ali would be his successor.
answers_formatted: Nowruz [or Persian New Year; or Iranian New Year; prompt on New Year]
cleaning one's house [or spring cleaning; accept sweeping; accept obvious equivalents like decluttering]

bonuses.leadin: This staunch anti-communist explained her shift of support to the Republicans and claimed that the Somozas and the Shah were less cruel than leftist regimes in her article "Dictatorships and Double Standards." For 10 points each:
answers: Soviet-Afghan war [or the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this neoconservative Reagan-era Ambassador to the United Nations whose feuds with Alexander Haig over the Falklands War resulted in Haig's resignation.

Condoleezza Rice cited a weak response to this conflict as the reason why Jimmy Carter and the Democrats lost her vote. The CIA trained the mujahideen groups that evolved into the Taliban during this 1980's conflict which involved a coup in Kabul.

This former "Goldwater Girl" broke from the Republicans due to the Vietnam War. She chaired the 1993 task force on National Health Care reform and was investigated for suspect cattle futures trading with Tyson Foods.
answers_formatted: Soviet-Afghan war [or the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan; prompt on partial answers]

bonuses.leadin: A novel titled for this character is interrupted by Frances Vane's "The Memoirs of a Lady of Quality." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who is adopted by the cannon-obsessed Commodore Hawser Trunnion. This character's journey from scamming the nobles of Bath with magic tracks to Fleet Debtors Prison inspired Charles Dickens's early novels.
The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle was written by this Scottish author. This author penned the picaresque novel The Adventures of Roderick Random after translating Don Quixote to English.
This author argued that George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion was lifted from Peregrine Pickle. An unrelated Peter Smollett convinced Jonathan Cape to refuse to publish this author's novel Animal Farm.

bonuses.leadin: The USS Samuel B. Roberts was struck by a mine while en route to escort these vehicles. For 10 points each:
answers: oil tankers [or crude tankers; or product tankers; accept the Tanker War prompt on less specific answers such as ships]
parts: Name these vehicles. Operation Earnest Will was launched to protect these vehicles from Iranian attacks during a phase of the Iran-Iraq War commonly named for them.

In the Tanker War, Iran mined this strategic waterway to prevent oil tankers from entering and exiting it into the Gulf of Oman. Operation Praying Mantis was focused around denying access to this waterway.
Operation Earnest Will specifically aimed to protect tankers operated by this country. In a later war, this country's oil fields were set on fire during the retreat of invading Iraqi forces.
answers_formatted: oil tankers [or crude tankers; or product tankers; accept the Tanker War prompt on less specific answers such as ships]
acceptable: Tanker War prompt on less specific answers such as ships

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about vowel shifts in English. For 10 points each:
answers: Middle English [accept Early Middle English or Late Middle English]
parts: The Great Vowel Shift describes phonological changes in this stage of English that immediately followed Old English.

In the Great Vowel Shift, some front vowels underwent this kind of change, in which two contrasting sounds become a single sound. Some examples of them in American English include those named pin-pen and cot-caught.
William Labov identified this vowel shift in American English, which began with speakers raising short A. It has led speakers transitioning to a cot-caught merger in places like Pittsburgh.
answers_formatted: Middle English [accept Early Middle English or Late Middle English]

bonuses.leadin: High-intensity focused ultrasound is a minimally-invasive procedure still in trial to treat this cancer. For 10 points each:
answers: inflammation [or the inflammatory response; accept proliferative inflammatory atrophy]
parts: Name this cancer, which may be tested for by measuring its impacted organ's namesake "specific antigen." It and another related disease are tested for with a digital rectal exam.

This system for assessing the stage of prostate cancer assigns a value between 2 and 10 based on patterns observed in biopsy samples. The final grade is the sum of the two most dominant patterns, with the number being doubled if only one pattern is seen.
Prostate cancer may arise when this phenomenon afflicts the prostate, which is termed PIA. This phenomenon is a common immune response in which a target area becomes redder, hotter, and more swollen.

bonuses.leadin: In a film, this instrument begins playing as a woman turns on a light next to a dark Vienna street, revealing a smirking man in a doorway who the protagonist had thought was dead. For 10 points each:
answers: zither [accept specific types of zithers such as a concert zither]
parts: Name this instrument, which also plays at the end of a speech in which a character describes how, in five hundred years of peace, the only thing Switzerland produced was the cuckoo clock.
Anton Karas used only the zither in his score for this Carol Reed film noir, in which the pulp writer Holly Martins investigates the death of his friend Harry Lime, who is actually alive.
This actor delivered the famous "cuckoo clock" speech as Harry Lime in The Third Man. He played the title role in Citizen Kane, a film he also directed.
answers_formatted: zither [accept specific types of zithers such as a concert zither]
acceptable: specific types of zithers such as a concert zither

bonuses.leadin: This man attacked "rootless cosmopolitans" in an antisemitic campaign. For 10 points each:
answers: Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union [accept People's Commissar for Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Union]
medical doctors [accept clear knowledge equivalents such as physicians; accept a medical person; accept the Doctor's Plot]
parts: Name this man, accused by Leon Trotsky of exploiting antisemitism in his Great Purge of the Soviet government.
Maxim Litinov held this role in the Soviet Union under Stalin. His successor in this role lost his job when his wife Polina, who was the head of the Ministry of Light Industry, was arrested.

Stalin falsely accused primarily Jewish members of this profession of attempting to assassinate him towards the end of his life, leading to numerous arrests. Khrushchev acknowledged that those charges against this profession were fabricated in the Secret Speech.
answers_formatted: Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union [accept People's Commissar for Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Union]
medical doctors [accept clear knowledge equivalents such as physicians; accept a medical person; accept the Doctor's Plot]
acceptable: Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union
